Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises in the middle of a runway. Jamie and the Doctor come out.

Dialogue.Line: It's a flying beastie!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An aeroplane is coming in to land, flaps down. Jamie and the Doctor run, followed by Ben and Polly. It aborts its landing, missing them and heading off back into the sky. A patrolling policemen sees the running group.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, you! Stop!
Scatter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben goes one way, while the Doctor, Jamie and Polly go another. The policemen intercepts Ben.

Dialogue.Line: The pilot said what?
A police box on the runway.
A likely story. Tell him to get back into stack and await further instructions.
Yes sir.
Miss Rock, get the Airport Police.
Gatwick Control, Sugar Delta X-Ray. Return to stack.
Police? Commandant here. In-bound aircraft reports obstruction on intersection of runways Five and Two. Investigate and report back. Police Box.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two motorcycle police ride off to investigate, then escort a low-loader carrying the Tardis off the runway. The policeman has failed to catch Ben. The Doctor and Jamie are hiding behind the wheels of a parked aeroplane.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, come over here with me. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly comes out of a hangar to see the policeman walking away, so she ducks back inside.

Dialogue.Line: Just a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A grey-suited man comes down some wooden stairs.

Dialogue.Line: Give me that envelope!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer is an airline pilot, and he is pointing an alien weapon at the man.

Dialogue.Line: I would advise you to stop.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a pulsing sound and the man drops. Spencer picks up the envelope the man was carrying and drags the body a short way before covering it with what looks like parachute silk, then leaves. Polly has seen all this from behind some crates.
Spencer walks through an ordinary looking office, twists a can on a shelf and a secret door opens into a high-tech room. He turns on a monitor.

Dialogue.Line: Can you come quickly? Trouble. BLADE [on monitor]: Trouble? What happened?
The postcards. Someone found them. BLADE [on monitor]: Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ended, a buzzer sounds. A surveillance camera shows Polly uncovering the body.

Polly runs as Spencer comes out, weapon ready. Outside the hanger, Spencer is about to fire at her when the motorcycle police ride past. He puts the weapon away and goes back inside. Elsewhere, Ben watches the Tardis being delivered to a hangar.

Dialogue.Line: (into phone) All right, all right. So you dumped it by number four hangar, but what was it? It was a police box? (to Jean) Get me the police chief. All right, you can bring those planes down now. The obstruction's been cleared.
Right, sir.
Do you think it was some kind of practical joke, sir? Students or maybe someone?
Well, whoever it was they're going to pay for it as soon as I get my hands on them. I'm not going to have the lives of passengers endangered by practical jokers or anyone else.
Superintendent Reynolds? I have the Commandant for you. The Chief of Police.
Listen, what's all this about a police box on the runway? Oh. Well, security's got to be tightened up all round. He reports that four suspects were seen running away from it.
Did they catch them?
No. Idiot of a policeman lost them. They're probably miles away by now. Get me Immigration. Tell them to let me know if any suspicious characters are seen in the area.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jamie are hiding under another aeroplane.

Dialogue.Line: There's Polly!
Polly! Over here!
Doctor, I've just seen a man killed.
Hit by one of the beasties?
No, no. He was murdered by another man.
Get your breath, Polly, and tell us exactly what happened.
Well, I went into the hangar to get away from a policeman, and there were two men in there. One of them had a gun and he shot the other one.
The murderer, did he see you?
Well, he chased me, but I managed to lose him.
Could you find this hangar again?
Well, I think so. I can remember the name. It was Chameleon something or other. Hey, where's Ben?
We haven't seen him. Come on, let's find this hangar.
But listen. The bloke with the gun, he'll be looking for me.
Ah, we'll look after you. Now come on.
But where's? What about Ben?
Aye, we'll find him. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade is another pilot.

Dialogue.Line: Who was he?
He found the postcards.
His name?
I don't know. I caught him in the office. He found evidence. I had to stop him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade checks the man's wallet.

Dialogue.Line: You killed Detective Inspector Gascoigne. A policeman.
Do you think a parent sent him?
Possibly. It's doesn't matter The important thing is that nobody should find him. Arrange disposal.
All right. Get it over here as quickly as possible. A container is on the way.
Right. Destroy this. Why have you left those suitcases there?
The detective. He interrupted me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer puts the suitcases and wallet through a panel in the wall. There's a whirring sound each time. Then the buzzer sounds.

Dialogue.Line: Spencer! POLLY [on monitor]: Look. And, Doctor, the bloke came out of that door there. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Is it locked? Is anyone in there? No, its locked. There's nobody there.
Polly, this man that killed him. Would you recognise him again?
Well, yes. He chased me. I'd recognise him anywhere.
Fool.
Polly, how do you say he was killed?
With a gun.
Can you describe it to me?
No. It was too far away. Why?
This man was electrocuted. His clothes are all scorched!
It was definitely some kind of a gun, Doctor.
Maybe. But not one that's not been developed yet on this planet.
This man they call Doctor, where does he get his knowledge?
He looks like a normal being.
More intelligent then most. He is a threat to our operation.
I'll kill him.
No. Get the girl. She can identify you. We can deal with the man later.
He may talk.
So? Nobody will believe him.
We must report this to the authorities.
That man who chased us. We could find him maybe.
What, the policeman? Oh, no, no, Jamie. We must find the man in charge in this place.
But what about him? We can't just leave him here.
There's nothing else we can do. Now, let's find the main airport building. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer is hiding in another hangar as Jamie and the Doctor walk past.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure this is the right way, Doctor?
This seems to be leading to the main airport building.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer grabs Polly and fires a pen-like device at her. She is silent as he drags her away.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, what happened to me?
A temporary disablement. You'll be back to normal any second now. Up here.
Where are you taking me?
You'll soon find out.
I've got her.
Excellent. Did anybody see you this time?
She was following behind her friends, but they didn't notice.
They'll come looking for me.
Sit down.
Murderers.
You'll have to show us some respect, and answer my questions. Which airline do you work for?
I don't understand.
You must belong to some airline or the airport authority to be in this part of the airport.
I've got nothing to do with the airport. We'd just arrived. We were lost. I was trying to find someone to help me and I saw him kill a man.
You say you'd just arrived? How did you get here?
We'll gain nothing by questioning her. The important thing is that we've got her.
You don't think my friends are just going to forget me like that, do you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The buzzer sounds.

Dialogue.Line: I don't understand it, Doctor. Polly's nowhere to be seen. Something must have happened to her. DOCTOR [on monitor]: It's locked Jamie. There's nobody there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly tries to hammer on the door but Spencer grabs her.

Dialogue.Line: I'm afraid we're wasting our time here, Jamie. The sooner we find the authorities and tell it all to them, the better. Come on.
All right.
Yes, you're right. Your friends are worried about you. Well then, we shall have to do something to stop them worrying.
Would Doctor Scott, passenger recently arrived from Alderney on flight number JY17, please return to the ticket desk.
This seems to be the way, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They come to passport control.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me, we're looking for someone in authority.
Just a moment, sir. All in good time. Thank you, Madam. Now, sir, your passport please.
I've got no time for that. We want to see someone in authority!
I am in authority. Your passport, please.
You don't understand. We have something important to report.
Yes, sir. When you've found your passport. The next one, please.
What's a passport, Doctor?
Some sort of official mumbo-jumbo. Look! We've just discovered a dead body out there. Did you hear me?
Well, sir. If I were you I'd inform the police.
Then please tell me where we can find them.
There's probably a policeman in the main concourse,
And where is that?
Through this door and turn to your left.
Thank you. Thank you very much. Come on, Jamie.
May I see your passport, sir?
We neither of us have passports! Now does that satisfy you?
I think you must be mistaken, sir. You couldn't have got on the aircraft without passports.
What aircraft?
The one you arrived on, sir.
We didn't arrive on an aircraft.
Now look here, sir, this joke's gone on far enough. You know and I know that you must have arrived here on the last inbound flight, which was flight number 729 from Madrid.
Can we not tell him about Tardis? Ow!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stamps on Jamie's foot.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
It's the way we got here.
You gentlemen wouldn't know anything about a police box, would you?
That's just what I'm saying. We're. Ow!
I really think that our mode of conveyance is irrelevant. The important thing is that we've discovered a dead body out there and we want to report it to someone in authority.
I think you'll have plenty of opportunity to see someone in authority.
Well, thank you.
Will you take a seat please, over there?
Thank you very much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jenkins makes a telephone call.

Dialogue.Line: Give me the Commandant, please. Hello, sir, Jenkins here. Immigration desk number five. I think I've got two of your suspects here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben is walking past the hangar when he hears hammering. He goes inside to investigate. Blade is fastening a large crate before going into the office.

Dialogue.Line: Anyone here? There must be someone around. Anyone here?
Oh, hello, Is Captain Blade about?
Well, I don't know. I'm a bit lost.
Are you looking for me?
Yes, I have your flight schedules here. They're all in order.
Thank you.
Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jean leaves.

Dialogue.Line: And what do you want?
I'm looking for the way out, mate.
This is private property. Visitors are not welcome. Do you belong to the airport staff?
Yeah, I started today. But I didn't mean to come in here. I just got lost, see.
Are you sure?
Of course I am. Look, are you going to direct me or not?
Yes, of course. Come on, I'll show you the way.
You say this girl actually witnessed a murder?
Yes, she saw the man killed.
He was electrocuted with a ray gun.
A what?
Oh, what does it matter what sort of gun. The point is he was killed and my friend saw it happen.
Where is she? I'd like to talk to her.
Well, that's another thing. She's vanished.
Oh, people who vanish, ray guns. Is this some sort of joke?
You wouldn't think it a joke if you'd come and see the body.
What flight did these people come in on?
Well sir, they came with the passengers from flight 729 from Madrid, but they've no passports.
Perhaps you'd kindly explain why you have no passports?
Oh look, we're all wasting time. Now, are you going to come and see that body, or am I going to find someone who really is in charge in this place?
I am in charge in this place, thank you. Now, you'll both accompany me to this hangar immediately.
Well thank you. Thank you very much. At last.
Tell Air Traffic Control where I am.

Yes, sir. Immigration desk number five here. Number One's just gone to the hangar area. He wanted me to let you know. As a matter of fact, he has just gone to look for a dead body. Yes, It's going to be one of those days, isn't it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade selects a postcard of the Eiffel Tower, puts a French postage stamp on it then repeats with the next postcard.

Dialogue.Line: Get her?
She's being processed. They can take another on the next flight.
Excellent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade takes a hypodermic syringe from a tray, then opens a cabinet door. An inhuman arm reaches out. He injects it then the buzzer sounds.

Dialogue.Line: The body, it's gone.
You're quite sure you got the right hangar?
Aye, the name's up outside. The body was lying just here.
Well, let's see what we have got, shall we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses a magnifying glass to examine the concrete floor.

Dialogue.Line: What exactly are you doing?
For the police, of course. The trouble is, I can't tell them who he was.
Some sort of mystery man, no doubt?
Yes, as a matter of fact he was. There was nothing in his pockets to identify him.
Oh, a man with nothing in his pockets?
Yes, I was rather surprised myself. No, wait a minute, there was one thing.
What did he have in his pocket?
This.
A postage stamp?
Ah, but it's Spanish and it hasn't been used.
Oh, I am sure that'll make all the difference.
Exactly. Hello, this is interesting.
What have you found now?
It's burnt fibres.
What about this, Doctor? This wasn't here before. It's a burn mark.
You're right, Jamie. That's quite new. Well, it's good to see someone is using their intelligence.
Oh, I've had enough of this. You two are coming with me.
That was definitely made by a ray gun.
Ray gun, burnt fibres, foreign stamps.
Unused foreign stamps.
All right, unused foreign stamps. I must be as mad as you are even to be listening you.
You know what they've done with it, don't you?
Done with what?
The body. Somewhere there's a large packing case.
Right behind you, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie starts to pull at the lid. It says made in Poland, by the way.

Dialogue.Line: Can I help you?
Are you connected with Chameleon Tours?
Yes. I'm Captain Blade, Chief Pilot.
Ah, these gentlemen seem to think there's an incident happened in here.
An incident?
Would you mind if we had a look in this packing case?
May I ask who you are?
I'm the Commandant.
Yes, of course. What you expect to find?
A dead man.
How very interesting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade opens the case with a crowbar.

Dialogue.Line: Plastic cups! Now, I'm going to do some investigating of my own.
Well, I'm glad I've roused your interest.
Oh, but you have. And what I am going to investigate is you and why you're both here in the airport. Thank you, Captain Blade. Come on, you two. Out!
Come on, Jamie. We'd better humour him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Commandant, the Doctor and Jamie leave.

Dialogue.Line: Bring him down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A figure is helped to the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: All we can see is an inhuman hand.

Dialogue.Line: Will he survive?
If we hurry.
There you are. We've got to get you to the airport building and you'll be safe.
He's reaching suffocation point. Hurry.
If you'd had let me search the place properly we might have found

That hangar is leased to a private charter company. I've no right to search in there, let alone you. Now, will you kindly sit down and keep quiet. Jenkins, get on to Superintendent Reynolds. This is his job. These people are trespassing.
I've just got another flight coming through, sir.
All right, I'll do it.
Doctor, look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly has arrived at the desk and is getting out her passport. Meanwhile, Spencer and Blade are helping the mysterious figure up an escalator and through the airport concourse.

Dialogue.Line: Commandant, this is the girl I was telling you about.
I beg your pardon?
Do you know these gentlemen?
No. Why, should I?
According to them, they know you.
Now where have you been, Polly?
Polly? My name isn't Polly. You must have made a mistake. I've never seen them before in my life

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade pulls back a screen to reveal Meadows lying unconscious on another table.

Dialogue.Line: You're quite sure you've never met these men? They say they know you.
But they can't know me. This is my first visit to England.
But Polly, it's us. Me and the Doctor.
Would you mind telling us your name?
I am Michelle Leuppi from Zurich.
You have a passport?
Yes, of course. Here. Have I done something wrong?
Oh no, I don't suppose there's anything for you to worry about, Miss. May I just ask what you're doing in England?
I've come here to work. Look, here is my work permit.
Oh, yes, that's quite in order. Thank you. Excuse me.
Where did you learn such excellent English?
I had an English governess. Would you mind telling me what's happening?
Nothing that need concern you, miss, everything's perfectly order. Now, if you'd just like to go through there.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly lookalike Michelle leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Polly, wait!
Just a minute young man.
But she's a friend of ours and she saw the murder!
You're going to wait here until the Superintendent of police arrives, now understand that.
Ah, you're going to tell him about the dead body. Very sensible.
No. I am going to tell him about you. Put me through to Superintendent Reynolds, please.
(sotto) Jamie, I don't think we're very welcome here. When I say run, we run.
Hello, Super? Commandant. I've got a couple of illegal entrants here. Yes. Immigration desk number five.
Run!
Commandant!
Situation changed. They've just made a run for it. I'll give you their description.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A nurse enters.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, he's suffocating.
You were twenty minutes late.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She gets two arm bands from a cupboard, one black and one white. There is a tiny control panel in each one. Blade puts the white one on Meadow's forearm, while Spencer attaches the black one to the alien.

Dialogue.Line: Who is he?
Meadows, Air Traffic Control.
Good. He may be useful to us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The nurse puts headsets on both bodies and switches on the machine they are attached to. Meadows begins to twitch and the alien goes rigid.
Two policemen stride through the passengers. The Doctor and Jamie are sitting next to a newsstand, hiding behind broadsheets. Jamie has chosen a foreign one, and is holding it upside down.

Dialogue.Line: They're still hunting for us, Doctor.
Yes. We'll have to keep out of their way until we can prove our story.
A fine chance we have of doing that with Polly kidding on she doesnae know us.
I don't think Polly was kidding on. In fact I don't think that was Polly.
Of course, it was Polly. You saw her.
You don't want to believe everything you see, Jamie.
Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The policemen are coming back.

Dialogue.Line: All clear, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is reading his paper.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Jamie, what was the name of that hangar?
Polly said Chameleon something.
Yes, Chameleon Tours. An advertisement for Chameleon Youth Tours. Budget Tours for young people between the ages of eighteen and twenty five.
What do they mean by budget?
Inexpensive, cheap. This could be the bait. Do you know what a chameleon is, Jamie?
It's just a name, I suppose.

It's the name of a small animal, a lizard that can change it's colour to merge with it's background. But it's a name that could equally be applied to people as well. People who change their personalities to suit their own ends. Budget Tours. Young people between the ages of eighteen and twenty-five. Oh yes, there's something strange going on here.
Doctor! Jamie!
Ben, are you all right?
Yeah, I'm okay.
Well that's a relief.
What happened to you two, and where's Polly?
We can't talk here. We've got to find somewhere to hide. Something about passports.
I've got the very place. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The features of the alien are turning into those of Meadows. The real Meadows is covered with a sheet now. Nurse Pinto switches off the machine.

Dialogue.Line: Is he all right?
We'll see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She stabs the alien with a pin.

Dialogue.Line: Ow!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They help him to sit up facing an eye test chart.

Dialogue.Line: Read the first line.
(slurred) E T
Vocal control.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade adjusts a dial on the arm band.

Dialogue.Line: Try that.
H X O A

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stoppers are removed from two chemical bottles. Meadows 2 sniffs at one and likes it, but recoils from the other.

Dialogue.Line: All complete.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She hands a personnel file to Blade.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you?
My name is George Meadows. I work at Air Traffic Control, Gatwick Airport.
Where do you live?
Number Ten, Sylvia Avenue.
Number Ten?
Until last week we lived at Number Thirty-Four. I've been too busy to tell the Personnel Department of the change.
Excellent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Ben and Jamie are walking along when Ben sees someone at one of the kiosks.

Dialogue.Line: Look, there's Polly.
Yes. Look who she's working for.
Chameleon Tours.
Yes. Leave this to me. Polly.
Please go away.
Now, something has happened to you, Polly. I want you to try to remember up to the time we left the hangar.
I don't know what you're talking about.
Now think, Polly. There were three of us in the hangar. You were showing us something. Now, what was it?
I tell you, I don't know what you're talking about.
The hangar, Polly. The Chameleon Hangar. You said you'd seen the man who did it.
I didn't see anything. I think you're mad. If I'd seen anyone shot, I'd have gone to the police.
Anyone shot?
I mean murdered
I didn't say anyone was shot or murdered, Polly.
(upset) Look, please, will you just leave me alone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor returns to Ben and Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: What's happened to her, Doctor?
I don't know, but I mean to find out. Come on, let's find that place where we can talk.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Michelle watches them leave, she is being watched by Blade on a monitor in a room at the rear of the kiosk.

Dialogue.Line: Come in here. I was going to brief you for this assignment, but there isn't any purpose now.
I have failed then?
Circumstances are against you. I'll make arrangements for you to leave on the next flight.
Back to base.
Yes.
What about that man? He's very persistent.
Don't worry about him. We have ways of dealing with such people.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meadows 2 relieves another air traffic controller. Jean Rook enters and sees the Commandant being questioned by a man with a slight Scottish accent and smoking a pipe.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure you haven't seen him, sir?
I'm quite sure. Oh Jean, this is Detective Inspector Crossland. Give him any help you can. If you'll excuse me?
Yes, of course, sir.
Well now, Inspector, what can I do for you?
Well, I think I'll need a pass for a start.
Well, that's easily arranged. Anything else?
Yes, I was supposed to meet a colleague of mine here. Detective Inspector Gascoigne.
Yes?
Well, he was investigating a missing person off one of your charter flights. The funny thing is, he hasn't shown up.
Detective Inspector Crossland. What shall I say your business is?
Investigation into Chameleon Youth Tours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three grown men into one photo booth doesn't really go.

Dialogue.Line: What is this place?
It's a machine that takes your photograph.
Photograph?
Well, you see, you've got your
No, Ben, not now. What puzzles me is this girl pretending to be Polly, yet in a way she is Polly.
Do you think she's been brainwashed?
No, not in the time. Whatever happened to her happened to her in a few minutes. Look out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The curtain is pulled back by an elderly lady. Surprised, she pulls it back again and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: All right. Now Ben, Jamie, we've got to find out more about Chameleon Youth Tours, but the trouble is, we're not free to move around with the authorities looking for us.
Well, they're not looking for me.
No, that's true. You could investigate the hangar.
(Leave it to me. Now what about you?
I'm going back to the Commandant and try and convince him that there's a murderer abroad.
Well I'll go with Ben.
No, Jamie, I want you to find your way back to the Chameleon kiosk and keep an eye on Polly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The come out of the booth and split up. Jamie is a little lost and wanders around.

Dialogue.Line: Further call for flight BR129 to Geneva now boarding through channel B at gate number 19.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A dark-haired liver bird approaches, played by Pauline Collins.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, er, are you in charge here?
Yes. Can I help you?
Yes. I'm Samantha Briggs and I've come down from Liverpool.
Oh, really.
It's about my brother, Brian Briggs.
What about him?
He went on one of your tours, and now he's disappeared.
I'm sorry, I don't follow.
Well, it's really very simple. I tried to get the telephone number of the hotel you sent him to, and the operator said there was no such place.
Well, the operator must have been mistaken then.
So, I got in touch with the police and they said that Brian wasn't staying at any hotel in Rome.
Well, perhaps he changed his mind and decided to go off on a different tour then.
Yes? Well what about this then? A postcard from Brian posted in Rome.
Yes, that does seem odd, doesn't it. Er, would you like me to make some enquiries, for you?
Well, what do you think I've come all the way down from Liverpool for?
Well, since you've put the matter with the police, why have you?
The police. They said that dozens of people go missing every week and they haven't got the men to go chasing after them all.
I see. What did you say your brother's name was?
Brian Briggs. Would you like me to spell it for you?
That won't be necessary, thank you. I'll see what I can find out, if you don't mind waiting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Michelle calls up the office on the monitor.

Dialogue.Line: Is Captain Blade there? SPENCER [on monitor]: No.
Well, I must speak with him urgently. Enquiries about a missing passenger. SPENCER [on monitor]: I'll tell him to contact you. He shouldn't be long.
The gentleman I wanted to speak with wasn't available. They're trying to find him. Do you want to wait?
Well, I've got nothing else to do, have I? I'll be over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She goes to sit near Jamie, who is hiding behind another newspaper.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, blast.
Is anything the matter?
Stuck up thing!
What?
Not you. That girl. She just couldn't care less.
About finding your brother.
Yes.
I couldn't help overhearing. Do you think something's happened to him?
Well, that's just it, I don't know. Oh, Brian can take care of himself all right, but still.
Aye, well I hope you're right.
What do you mean?
I might just be able to help you. I can't tell you anything at the moment but later I'd like you to meet a friend of mine. I'm sure he'll know what's best.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie hides behind his newspaper as a policeman walks past.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me, sir. There's a gentleman to see you.
Did he say what about?
Well yes. It's about a dead body.
Bring him in.
Would you come in, please?
Thank you. Ah, Commandant. How nice to see you again.
(into telephone) Airport Police please.
At least hear what I have to say.
I've heard all I want to from you. What do you mean, they're engaged. This is the Commandant. Thank you.
If you're going to speak to the police, then tell them that there's something happening in this airport that may endanger human lives.
Hello, police? Commandant. Would you send a couple of men down here at once please.
Well, since I'm obviously about to be arrested, may I make one last request? Listen to me for just one minute!
Not for one second. I've heard all I want to hear about burnt fibres, ray guns, disappearing people.
But there was a dead body in the Chameleon Tours hangar.
Did you say Chameleon Tours?
Why, do you know something about it?
Well no, but the Inspector Crossland wanted to know
All right, Jean. I'll handle this. Take this man away, put him under lock and key and keep him there.
One step nearer and I'll blow you all to smithereens! Catch!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has gone, leaving the Commandant holding a small rubber ball.

Dialogue.Line: All right, after him.
That's quite clear, is it? You know what to tell her? MICHELLE [on monitor]: I do.
As soon as you've got rid of the girl, close the kiosk and get on the next flight.
Miss Briggs.
Yes. Have you found anything?
Er, well yes, I have, but I'm afraid it doesn't help very much. Your brother definitely did get on our flight to Rome, but what he did when he got off the plane, I couldn't tell you.
Well, if you can't, who can?

Miss Briggs, we're dealing with thousands of passengers every week. We can't keep track of every single one. If I were you, I'd go back to Liverpool. I'm sure your brother will turn up eventually. Now if you'll excuse me, I have to close this kiosk.
Thanks for nothing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Polly/Michelle puts a Closed sign on the counter and Samantha goes back to Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: There's something funny going on here.
Why?
My brother's vanished, and that lot just couldn't care less.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben has returned to an empty hangar. There are new packing cases in one corner, so Ben levers one open. It contains a catatonic Polly, eyes staring at nothing. Ben runs upstairs.
Ben grabs the telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Hello? What's the name of the man who's in charge of this airport? The Commandant? Right, well look, can you put me through to his office, please? All right, then Air Traffic Control. But I want to speak to a friend of mine who should be with the Commandant right now.
Doctor, I'd like you to meet this young lady.
What young lady? Where's Polly?
She's still inside.
Ah, I shan't be a minute.
Polly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is empty. There's a model aeroplane on the desk and the monitor shows the concourse. A search of the desk produces blank postcards from various foreign countries, together with sheets of unused foreign stamps. The Doctor fiddles with the model plane and the monitor picture changes. First the medical centre, then the hangar office.

Dialogue.Line: But why wouldn't you listen to him? It's all true. I'm in the Chameleon Hangar now and I've just f
Ben! Ben, can you hear me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer has walked in and fired a pen-shaped device at Ben.

Dialogue.Line: Ben, can you hear me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ben is rigid.
Spencer hangs up the telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Ben, are you all right? Can you hear me? Ben! Ben! Ben, can you hear me?
Who is he?
A friend of that Doctor on the screen.
Did he see what happened in there?
He must have done.
Then he'll be coming here. We'd better be prepared for him. First, dispose of the body.
Who is he?
His name's Brian Briggs. He's supposed to have come through here about a week ago on holiday.
Thousands of people come through here in a week.
Aye, well it was just a chance. Do you remember that man?
Oh yes, I remember him. He had a pass. But I can't remember his name.
He's a colleague of mine. Detective Inspector Gascoigne. Now when did he come back?
I couldn't tell you. There are so many faces. There was a bit of bother this morning. He could have slipped through then.
What sort of bother?
Two people without passports, who told some story about a body in a hangar.
What happened?
Ah, it was all a hoax. These two men they ran away. The airport police are still looking for them.
Can you describe them to me?
One was a scruffy-looking man, medium-height, wearing a frock-coat. the other was a Scots boy dressed in a kilt.
Oh, they shouldn't be too hard to find.
Hey, you think we should go after your friend? He's been gone about ten minutes now.
No, he said half a hour. Now we'll do what he said.
Hey, he's a right weirdy, isn't he?
No! I wish I had his brains.
You're all right as you are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sam moves closer to Jamie. A woman in airline uniform - Ann Davidson - removes the closed sign from Chameleon Tours' kiosk.

Dialogue.Line: Chameleon Youth Tours announced the departure of their flight Number 413 to Zurich. Will all passengers please assemble in the departure lounge. Chameleon Youth Tours ann
Hey. Hey, look, they've opened up that kiosk now.
Aye, and where's Polly?
Will all passengers please assemble in the departure lounge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor finds Spencer's pen weapon. He knows he saw Spencer leave the room on the kiosk monitor, but there are no doors in the right direction.

Dialogue.Line: Packing cases.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The uniformed woman is addressing the group of youths at the kiosk.

Dialogue.Line: I'm quite sure the first thing you want to do when you get to Switzerland is write home to your parents, but in case you don't have time, Chameleon Tours have some postcards of Zurich ready for you to write here. When you've finished your postcards, give them back to me and we'll post them for you in Zurich.
Er, do you mind?
No, go ahead.
Look, a postcard of Zurich, stamped with a Swiss stamp, all ready to post.
Well?
Oh, you're a right one, aren't you. Don't you see. This could explain the card I got from Brian. It was posted in Rome, but that doesn't mean to say that he posted it.
Oh, I see. We'd better tell the Doctor about this. How long's he been gone?
Er, about half a hour, now.
Right, I'll go and find him.
I'll come with you.
Just a minute, son. I want a word with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is also trying to open a packing case. He finds Meadows staring back at him.

Dialogue.Line: Somebody help me, please. I'm suffocating. Quickly, somebody help me, please. I'm suffocating.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor manages to block the icy gas with his handkerchief, so Spencer flicks another switch and more gas comes out of an upper nozzle instead. The Doctor stands on a chair and blocks that too. Then he notices the CCTV camera and hangs his jacket over it. Spencer slides the door panel aside and comes out of the secret room to find the Doctor lying on the floor. He goes over and gets dosed with his own pen weapon. The Doctor retrieves his coat and makes his escape, leaving Spencer stiff on the floor. The Doctor runs out of the hangar past the still Meadows wearing the white armband.
By the Chameleon Tours kiosk.

Dialogue.Line: Yeah, but what about me brother?
I'm afraid I've got something more serious to look into first, Miss. If this young man's telling the truth, a colleague of mine's been murdered.
Ah, Doctor. There's a man here wants to talk to you.
Oh, who is he?
Er
There you are, sir.
Detective Inspector Crossland, Scotland Yard.
Aye, I've told him everything.
Have you ever seen that man?
Well, that's the man we found in the Chameleon Tours hangar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer blinks and sits up. Blade enters.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor's body. Where is it?
He escaped. His intelligence is far above normal beings.
Above yours, perhaps. I must leave. the flight to Zurich is ready to take off. You will remain here.
For what purpose?
To atone for your incompetence. The Doctor must die, and you must do it.
All right then, Doctor, we'll go and see the Commandant. I want him to hear your story.
Well, he wasn't every impressed with it the last time.
This time, he's going to believe you.
Well, if you think so. Jamie, stay here and keep an eye on the kiosk. We shan't be long.
And don't worry about your brother, Miss. We'll find him for you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Crossland leave.

Dialogue.Line: A fat lot of good that Inspector's going to be.
Ah, but he believes us.
Oh yeah, but that doesn't mean to say he's going to do anything. I think I'll go and have a look round that Chameleon Hangar.
Ah, not by yourself.
Well, I suppose it would be better if I had a man with me.
Aye. Oh, if only the Doctor hadn't told me to watch this place.
Oh, do you always do everything you're told?
No. But the Doctor trusts me.
Yeah, that's your trouble isn't it. All right, stay here. After all, they can only murder me. Ta-ra.
No, wait a minute. I don't suppose anything'll happen here, do you?
Well since they closed the kiosk, it's hardly likely.
And we won't be long away, will we?
Well, that depends on what we find. Ah, come on, kid.
In any case, you'll need me to show you the way there.
All right, all right, I'll accept that you found a body, but I still want to know where you come from and why you have no passport.
Oh, but surely that's unimportant. If
It is not unimportant to break the law.
Sir, I think we're going to have to let him tell us in his own way.
Oh, very well. Make it brief.
Thank you. I have just carried out a search of the Chameleon Tours hangar. In a packing case, I found the body of a man.
You never told me that, Doctor. Another dead man?
No, he was in a stupefied state, a sort of coma.
Who's this one?
I don't know his name but I have a feeling he's one of your employees.
Oh, indeed.
In fact, I think he may be in here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tours the ranks of air traffic controllers.

Dialogue.Line: Taxi, following southern taxi way for departure runway two seven.
Do you know what this is?
It looks like a fountain pen to me.
Things are not always what they seem. Oh careful, it's dangerous. Chameleon Tours are not quite what they seem either.
Oh? And what's your theory?
Well, I'm afraid you won't believe it when you hear it. However. First, Inspector Gascoigne was murdered with a ray gun.
A ray gun?
A weapon that has not yet been developed on this Earth.
Oh, really!
There, you see? I knew you wouldn't believe it. What's the use?
No, now be patient, sir. We are trying to understand you.
Very well. Next, I believe Chameleon Tours to be merely a front, a cover.
For what?
For the mass kidnapping of young people.
And is all this supposed to be taking place in my airport?
Yes, at this very moment!
Oh, that's quite enough. Can't you take that fellow into custody?
Well, I'm very sorry, sir, but you know he hasn't broken any law, except for this immigration business, and that's not my responsibility.
But Brian Briggs is your responsibility.
And who is he?
He's a young man who went on a Chameleon Tour and vanished.
Now, come on Doctor, wait a minute. We're not certain of that yet.
Well, he's nowhere to be found.
Well, no.
And neither are my two friends. Which to my mind proves my point. Chameleon Tours are a cover for the abducting of young people.
And just where do you think they're taking them?
Well, in view of the facts that I've already presented, the ray gun, this pen and one or two other things, I think we're dealing with people who are not from this planet.
That hardly answers my que. What did you say?
You see, I knew you wouldn't believe me.
Oh, this is absolute, arrant nonsense/
Er, look, Doctor, I think you ought to produce some evidence to support all this.
Evidence? What about this pen?
A pen! Do you call that evidence?
I'll demonstrate it for you. Excuse me. Would you mind helping us?
I don't understand.
Could you hold this cup out in front of you?
Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meadow stands, holding the cup, then sees the pen weapon.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, perhaps you've seen one of these before?
No, no I

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor fires at the cup, Meadow drops it and runs. Jean picks up the pieces.

Dialogue.Line: It's turned to ice.
Do you call that arrant nonsense?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha finds the envelope of pre-stamped postcards home.

Dialogue.Line: Dear Mum and Dad, have arrived safely in the Black Forest. Will write again soon. Love, Tim. Dear Dad, I. Dear Mum. Jamie!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is searching a packing case.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, look what I've found. There must be fifty postcards here. That should make that inspector do something.
Aye, you're right, and I know where to find him. You're a brave wee lassie. No time to greet now.
Oh, get off. I've got something in me eye. Come on. Where are we going?
The Commandant's office.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is sitting at a desk, looking over a sheaf of papers.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Hmm?
Here are the remaining flight schedules for Chameleon tours you wanted.
Thank you, my dear.
What a nasty little device.
I think I'd better get that checked over, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Samantha rush in.

Dialogue.Line: What the devil?
Doctor! Samantha, down here. Doctor, picture postcards. Look at them.
This is the limit. I will not have my control room invaded.
What, not even for these?
Why? What have you got there?
I think it's the further evidence you required, Inspector. Yes, just as I thought.
Where'd you get these?
In the office in that hangar. You see what they mean?
All falling into pattern. This envelope is addressed to somewhere in Germany.
Yeah, Dem Chameleon Reisen, Freiberg. That means Chameleon Tours.
Just what are you all talking about?
Well, you see. They give out these cards and get the kids to write home to their parents before they go. Then the Chameleon Tours lot take the cards abroad and they post them back to Britain.
So the parents think the children have arrived safely.
Doctor, what do you think does happens to them?
Now, now, now, this is all mere supposition.
Oh, to you, maybe. But one of those kids happens to be my brother.
Your brother?
Aye, sir. This is the young lady whose brother's missing, and you see, she did get a card from him in Rome.
But why would anyone want to abduct these young people?
Well, if we knew that we wouldn't be sitting here.
Inspector, can I have a word with you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They move away from the desk.

Dialogue.Line: You don't think this fellow's a little unbalanced, do you?
Oh maybe a wee bit unorthodox, sir, but after all, he's given us the only lead we've got so far. If you could just see your way to giving him a free hand.
A free hand?
Just to poke around a little bit, sir.
Do you think it's safe to let the fellow roam round the airport?
You can rely on us to keep an eye on him, sir.
All right, but on your head be it.

I personally will investigate Chameleon Tours. Then I'll report back to you here if I've found out anything. But in the meantime, if you could just keep everything going as normal, you understand? We don't want them to get wind of anything.
No, no, no, no, no. Doctor, I'll give you the freedom of the airport for twelve hours, heaven help me. At the end of that time I shall expect you back here with some real facts this time.
Thank you, Commandant.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha hugs Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Did they believe the Doctor?
I don't know.
What do you mean?
I think he suspects me. He turned one of our own weapons on me, forced me to leave.
You fool. You should have stayed. Now we do not know how much he has discovered.
Even if he has discovered the secret of our mission here, they will never believe him. These Earth minds cannot stretch that far.
Of course, the truth is beyond their intelligence. Except for that Doctor.
I know where he is. I could kill him.
You're going to, but not at the risk of your own safety. We still need you in Air Traffic Control.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer takes a button-sized item from a filing cabinet drawer.

Dialogue.Line: Here, take this attach it to him. When we are ready I shall activate the mechanism with this. That should put paid to him once and for all.
Very well.
Don't delay. I want him dead before Captain Blade returns.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The group are by an Air Traffic Controller separate from the main group, watching the radar.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I've made out a pass for you and for your two friends.
Thank you very much.
Excuse me, sir. There's a Chameleon flight coming in now.
Ah.
Alpha Delta Sierra X-ray Lima calling Gatwick Airport control.
Gatwick Control to Alpha Delta Sierra X-ray Lima.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meadows enters.

Dialogue.Line: Gatwick Control to Alpha Delta Sierra X-ray Lima. I will now give you your heading.
How many flights do they use a day?
Seven or eight.
How many planes do they use?
Four. I could get their registration numbers if you like? Why do you ask?
Eight flights a day and only four planes. Is that normal?
Oh, yes. They have a very quick turn around. I mean, after all they're only on short haul flights. You know, all the holiday centres. Spain, Rome, Athens, the Black Forest.
Jean, where's the file on winter schedules.
Excuse me.
Which is the Chameleon plane?
Oh that one, sir. Look, he's turning left at Dunsfold. I shall hold him now over Epsom until I can give him landing clearance.
What's the range of your radar?
Hundred and thirty miles, sir. Why?
I was just wondering when this plane first appeared.

I've no idea, sir. We don't notice them till they start to call in. Oh, excuse me a moment. Gatwick Control to Alpha Delta Sierra X-ray Lima. Climb to ten thousand feet and hold in Epsom control zone to wait landing clearance.
Alpha Delta Sierra X-ray Lima to Gatwick Airport. Climbing to ten thousand feet and holding.
Ah, you were saying, sir?
How long do you hold them after take off?
Once they've left Gatwick control zone we've finished with them.
Oh, I see. That means they might be anywhere.
Aren't you rather wasting your twelve hours hanging around here, disturbing my people?
I don't think I've been wasting a minute, but I'll go if you insist. Sam, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meadows bumps into the Doctor and puts the little device on his back.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry.
Oh, it's all right. It's quite my fault. Haven't I met you somewhere before?
I don't think so.
You must have a double.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer is manning the desk. He finishes dealing with a young lady.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, thank you.
Excuse me, are you the manager?
I'm looking after bookings. Can I help?
I'd rather like to speak to the manager. I'm a police officer.
Is there some trouble?
I'd prefer to speak to the person in charge.
Well, that's Captain Blade. He's just returned from one flight, he's taking off for another. He's rather busy at the moment.
Perhaps I could go out to the plane.
I'll have to see about that. Just a moment, please.
A detective wants to see you. BLADE [on monitor]: Does he suspect anything?
I don't know. BLADE [on monitor]: All right, send him over to the plane. We'll deal with him.
Are you sure this is the right room, Doctor?
Jamie, have you ever known me to be mistaken?
Aye.
Hey. Now watch out.
What?
That's the wall the gas-nozzles came out of.
Well, there's nothing here now.
You're right. Well, that's clever. That's very clever. Oh well, makes life simpler for us. Now, the man I froze came from here somewhere.
Aye, he would. A solid wall.
Well. somewhere in that solid wall there's a door.
Aye, and we still haven't found Ben and Polly. What do you think's happened to them?
I don't know. Perhaps if we find that door, we'll find them. Come on, you take that end, I'll take this.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor starts emptying the shelves from the bottom.

Dialogue.Line: We must hurry. Inspector Crossland's keeping them busy at the moment, but he'll be no match for them. If he presses them too far.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann Davidson is taking passenger's jackets and putting them in the overhead compartments.

Dialogue.Line: You'll find that the whole plane conforms strictly to the International Standards of air safety. I can't think why anybody should have complained about us?

Did I say anyone had complained? I'm not enquiring about safety. My enquires are about a missing boy. A passenger on one of your flights. And there's also the business of a colleague of mine, Detective Inspector Gascoigne, who was last seen in your hangar. He's believed to have been murdered.
That is indeed a much more serious matter.
Aye, I'm afraid I'm going to have to ask you to hold up this flight a while, while I ask you some questions. If you wouldn't mind coming to the Commandant's office?
Well, if you'll just excuse me for a moment, Inspector, I have some arrangements to make.
Excuse me, please.
Aye, I'm sorry lass.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade and Davidson go forward. Crossland even thinks about lighting his pipe. Then the engines start up. Crossland goes forward.

Dialogue.Line: Captain Blade.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: This is not a standard flight deck. No throttle controls or the usual displays.

Dialogue.Line: I shouldn't move any further if I were you. This gun proved remarkably effective in dealing with your colleague, Inspector Gascoigne.
You killed him.
Unfortunately an error. You Earth men are more use to us alive. Sit down there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann straps Crossland into the seat.

Dialogue.Line: That's better. This Earthman is a particularly fine specimen, don't you think?
Perhaps the Director himself.
Exactly.
Look, I don't know what you two are planning for me, but I must warn you of the long arm of the British law.
I don't think it'll reach where you're going. Chameleon Flight four one three to control. Request start up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The last item on the shelf is the control to the secret room.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, look!
Hey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door slides shut behind them. The Doctor opens a large cabinet with a sort of air conditioning unit inside.

Dialogue.Line: What's that, Doctor.
Someone who's not used to the Earth's atmosphere. Very interesting. Ah, a TV monitor set. Let's see what we can see.
Hey, what's that?
Well it looks like a hospital. Jamie, we're getting warmer, which is a change from the last time I was here. Come on, let's see if there's a First Aid post in Gatwick Airport.
Should we clear up the mess, Doctor?
No, let's get along to the first aid post.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer uses his remote control device to activate the 'button' on the Doctor's coat.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, my back!
What?
Jamie, my back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor collapses. Jamie spots the device and picks it off his jacket before stamping on it. He clutches his fingers after touching it.

Dialogue.Line: Please take a barley sugar. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Now the passenger can deal with the change in air pressure. She moves on.

Dialogue.Line: You can unfasten your seat belts now. Thank you. Barley sugar? Thank you. Everything all right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is trying to wake the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
He's dead. You're coming with me.
I'll not leave him.
You have five seconds to change your mind.
You'll have to kill me then.
I said five seconds. Five, four, three
Samantha!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha jumps out of hiding. Spencer turns and Jamie jumps him, making him drop the pen weapon. Samantha kicks it away, but Spencer has a second one and uses it on the pair of them. He picks up the first weapon, then starts setting up a laser. Once it is ready and working, Spencer sets the beam to move across the floor towards the helpless trio, then leaves.
Ann leaves with a metal container.

Dialogue.Line: I suppose there's no use my asking where this plane's going to?
You will know soon enough. This is Plane number three to Base. Inform the Director that I have an original for him as ordered. I am delivering him now, and will return immediately to Gatwick Airport.
Jamie? Are you all right?
Aye. They've not harmed you, have they?
No, but I can't move.
Doctor?
Are you all right?
What's happening? I can't move. What's that?
I don't know. It's a beam of light.
Aye. Doctor, it's moving towards us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The laser beam ignites a pile of wood shavings.

Dialogue.Line: That's just a small foretaste of what'll happen to us if we don't move and quickly.
But I can't move, Doctor.
Neither can I. Oh, wait a minute. I can move one arm. But I can't move away.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha can just reach her handbag.
Nurse Pinto is transforming another chameleon, using Jenkins from Immigration as the template.
Our heroes are starting to get some movement back.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Doctor, can't you do anything to stop it?
No. Wait. One thing. It's a long chance but it just might work. Have you got a mirror in that bag?
Yes.
Let's see. Yes, that'll do. Hand it to me.
I can't.
I can't move my hand. Jamie, can you take it?
Have you got it?
No. Careful.
Take it.
Got it.
Right now, see if you can point it at that laser gun.
Ay?
That thing on the wall.
I'll try, Doctor. But why?
Well, if you can reflect the light back, we've got a chance.
Can't you prop it up on something?
No, it won't work. I'll have to hold it.
But your hand.
It's a risk I'll have to take.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The beam is nearly on them.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, Jamie, now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie adjusts the mirror, reflecting the beam back to its projector. It explodes.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, well done.
Why, I can move.
I wonder if
Do you think that's what happened to Ben and Polly, Doctor?
No.
Are you sure?
I think they were needed for some purpose.
And we weren't.
We were obviously too dangerous for them.
But to try and do something like this in broad daylight.
Yes. It means only one thing, I'm afraid. Their plans are almost complete. We'll have to act fast if we're going to save Polly and Ben.
And Brian. Or have you forgotten about him.
No, I've not forgotten him, Sam, but if my guess is right they're all in the same place.
And where's that?
I don't know. Wait. The first aid post.
Ay?
We saw a first aid post on that monitor.
Aye.
We must find it. Well, come on. You're not going to sit there all day, are you? Just a minute. We can't all go down to the Medical Unit.
All right. What can I do?
Did you get a good look at the man who tried to kill us?
I'll say. I had me arms round his neck.
Go down to the Chameleon Kiosk and see if he comes in or out.
Right.
But be careful. Don't let him see you.
Me be careful? You two watch out for yourselves. I'll be okay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha picks up her mirror and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: She's got a lot of courage, that wee lass, Doctor.
Yes. I just hope she doesn't try to be too adventurous.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The new version of Jenkins is sitting up.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you? JENKINS 2: Steven Christopher Jenkins
Where do you live? JENKINS 2: With my parents in Wimbledon.
Employment? JENKINS 2: I'm an Immigration officer at Gatwick Airport.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor helps a half-conscious Jamie into the room.

Dialogue.Line: We'll have you as right as rain in a minute. Now just get you down here. There we are. Splendid.
(sotto) How am I doing, Doctor?
(sotto) Very well, but don't over do it. Yes, this is the room we saw on the TV monitor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nurse Pinto enters, leading Jenkins 2 out.

Dialogue.Line: If the tablets do not help, come and see me again. What's the matter with him?
It's a rare tropical disease, Nurse. I'm his doctor. If he if he doesn't rally soon we shall, we shall have to use somnalin.
Somnalin?
Yes, yes, somnalin. I shall have to get him somewhere to lie down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He opens the door to the x-ray room.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, yes, this will do nicely.
I'm afraid you can't go there.
Why not? It's just an x-ray room, isn't it? Isn't that a couch behind the screen.
I'm sorry, Doctor. You can't take your patient in there.
You refuse to help my patient?
Oh, it's not that. I have someone coming for an x-ray.
Oh I see. Well why didn't you tell me in the first place.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer and Jenkins 2 are watching on the monitor as the Doctor and Jamie leave.

Dialogue.Line: Let's get you out of here.
That Doctor is a menace to our plans. JENKINS 2: Then we must kill him.
I tried. He must have escaped. JENKINS 2: They won't escape me.
No, wait. This time, let them to come to us.
(on telephone) I've been paging him, Superintendent, but he hasn't responded. Yes, very well sir. I'll keep on trying. Operator. Look, I booked a call through to Athens. Now what's happened?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jamie enter.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, very well, I'll stay near the phone.
What's all this about?
Oh, Doctor, have you seen Inspector Crossland?
Well, no. Why?
Well, Scotland Yard are looking for him and we can't find him anywhere. Also, your Miss Briggs wants to see you.
But I told her to. Where is she now?
Well, she said something about going to the Chameleon Kiosk.
Go down and join her, Jamie. She's a very strong headed young woman. See she doesn't come to any trouble.
I'll keep an eye on her, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie leaves. Jean's telephone rings.

Dialogue.Line: Commandant, did the Inspector say where he was going?
Hmm? Oh, he said he was going to make some enquires about Chameleon Tours.
And now he's disappeared?
Aren't you rather jumping to conclusions?
I don't think so. My two friends became involved with Chameleon Tours and they've both disappeared. However, you know what I think's happened.
Yes, and you know what I think about your ridiculous theory. People from outer space, indeed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jean looks shocked.

Dialogue.Line: Something the matter with you?
Commandant, I've found out what's been happening.
Well, that's a step in the right direction.
What I mean is I took the liberty of phoning all the airports that Chameleon Tours fly to. The last on my list was Athens.
But don't you realise the expense of phoning Athens.
Yes, I know, I'm sorry. But what I found out is, they never deliver any passengers.
What do you mean? Never deliver any passengers.
It's absolutely true, sir. They all say the same thing. Dubrovnik, Athens, Rome. They say they pick up young passengers to take them off to other places, but none of them ever arrive anywhere.
Well in that case, they must be flying these young people to some secret airfield. But why?
You're still thinking in Earth terms.
And I intend to go on doing so. What was the name of that Chameleon Pilot?
Captain Blade.
And what time is the plane due back?
About half an hour sir.
Right. After the turn-round we'll have it followed this time.
Might I have a word with you, my dear?
Get me the RAF Station Manston.
I suspect that the Medical Centre is connected with all this.
Medical? Oh come on.
Now, please don't get like him. Oh yes, there is definitely a connection. Now, I would like to get in there and have a look round.
But anyone can go in there.
But I would like to get that nurse out of the way first. Do you think that you could manage it for me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha has just bought a ticket.

Dialogue.Line: You'll find that in order.
Ta.
He said you'd do something silly.
Oh yeah? What else did he say?
He said you were headstrong.

Oh great. Look, you can tell the Doctor he's not going to talk me out of this one, and neither are you. I'm going on the next Chameleon flight that leaves in half a hour. Oh look, don't you see it's the only way we can find out anything. Oh, don't worry. I'll come back and tell you all about it.
Aye, if you do come back.
Oh, it's only going to Rome.
And what makes you so sure you'll find your brother in Rome?
Oh, I don't know. But that's where he was supposed to be going. At least I'll be doing something.
Aye, but do you not realise how dangerous it is?
Look, if you're sacred, I'm certainly not.
I wish the Doctor were here.
Oh.
Hey, maybe I could go with you.
Hey, now you're talking. Do you think you can you raise the lolly?
The lolly?
The brass, the money. Look, it'll cost you twenty eight quid. Pounds to you.
Oh, but that's a fortune. I've never seen that much money in my life. I suppose I couldn't take your place?
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie spots the plane ticket in the top of her bag.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor said it was no job for a wee lassie.
A wee lassie? You can tell the Doctor.
I'll say goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie suddenly grabs Sam and kisses her.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, kid!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As they continue to embrace, Jamie takes her ticket and puts it inside his sweater.

Dialogue.Line: I can take care of myself, you know.
I just wanted to make sure.
(into phone) Hmm. So you can arrange to have it followed? Good. Oh, I'll find out. What time's the next Chameleon flight?
1530hrs to Rome, sir.

1530hrs heading south. Right. And I'll let you know when they request permission to start up. Cheerio, old man, and many thanks. Well, that's settled that. The next Chameleon flight will have an RAF fighter on its tail.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jean collapses into a chair, groaning.

Dialogue.Line: Good grief. Jean. Jean! What's the matter with the girl? Get me the Medical Centre.

(into phone) Isn't it possible for your assistant to come down here, Commandant? But I'm not supposed to leave here. All right, sir. If you insist. (Pinto picks up a medical bag and leaves. The Doctor enters and goes straight to

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor examines the alien transference device closely. Then he finds two electrical switches hidden in the couch. He plays with them, not noticing a screen sliding back to reveal the real nurse Pinto. She is wearing a white armband. The Doctor continues fiddling and the screen closes again. Now he checks a large cupboard and picks the lock with a screwdriver. Jenkins 2 has entered the medical centre and is watching through the doorway. He has a ray gun at the ready. The cupboard contains the supply of black and white armbands. The Doctor takes one of each and locks it up again before going to leave. A passenger enters the main room and Jenkins 2 hides his weapon. The Doctor comes out of the x-ray room.

Dialogue.Line: I'm just going off duty, but this gentleman will be pleased to attend to you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves, quickly.

Dialogue.Line: How do you feel?
Not too good.
I can't understand it. She's never done this on me before.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, Nurse. I feel much better now.
Well, there couldn't be much wrong then.
Have you had any lunch?
No, I've been so busy today, I haven't even had any breakfast.
Then no wonder you didn't feel well. Really, Commandant. You must see that your staff have time for regular meals.
I've never stopped her having her lunch.
I'm sure, Commandant. But it has been known to happen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Pinto leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Now look here, Jean.
Very well done.
Did I give you enough time?
Ample time.
What is all this? You weren't ill at all, were you?
It's all right, Commandant. She was acting on my instructions.
On your instructions?
Yes. What do you think of these?
Now, what are these?
I think there's somebody here who can tell us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds the two armbands and looks around for a certain ATC.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me. Where's the chap who usually sits there?
Well, he's probably off duty. In that case, he'll be back on shift in a couple of hours.
I see. Oh well, these'll have to wait.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann is checking passenger tickets.

Dialogue.Line: Chameleon Youth Tours announce the departure of their flight number 419 to Rome. Will all passengers please assemble in the departure lounge.
Don't forget your postcards. Give them back to me and we'll post them for you in Rome. Have you found your ticket yet?
I don't know. I seem to have lost it somewhere. But you remember me, don't you? I bought the ticket off you.
There are so many people. What was the name?

Samantha Briggs. Oh, it had S Briggs on the ticket. ANN [on monitor]: S Briggs has already checked in. SAMANTHA [on monitor]: Oh no. Well, who the heck? Look, can you remember what she looked like? ANN [on monitor]: She? I seem to remember a boy with that ticket. SAMANTHA [on monitor]: Jamie. He's pinched it. Look, you have to stop him. ANN [on monitor]: I can't hold up the flight. SAMANTHA [on monitor]: But look. ANN [on monitor]: I'm sorry, there's nothing more I can do for you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spencer phones through to the front desk

Dialogue.Line: Hello. Yes, all right. That's very kind of you. You're very fortunate. Your ticket's just been found.
Oh, good. Well who got it?
We can't tell you that, I'm afraid, but our manager would like to see you. He's just through there.
Oh right, ta.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha goes to the rear cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Now, who's got their postcards ready?
Er, you wanted to see me?
Yes, indeed. You won't escape again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, Jamie and the other young people are boarding their plane. What about his lack of passport? Oh well.

Dialogue.Line: Chameleon 419. Clearance correct.
Chameleon 419. Taxi Clearance.
Chameleon 419. Taxi following southern taxiway for departure runway 27.
Roger.
Well, this time they'll have the RAF on their tail.
How high can fighters go these days, Commandant?
Oh, ten miles plus.
How futile.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chameleon 419 takes off.

Dialogue.Line: RAF Manston, sir.
Oh, good. Hello, old boy. The Chameleon Rome flight's just taken off. They're on Amber one, at flight level 210. Right. Good man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A fighter plane takes off from Kent to intercept.

Dialogue.Line: You can unfasten your seat belts now. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is very pale.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
Oh aye, I'll be all right.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then Jamie makes a sprint for the rear toilets.

Dialogue.Line: That's the fifty mile mark they're passing now.
Normally you don't plot them at this range?
No, there's too much traffic to control. Once they're up and away on their air corridor, we're finished with them.
Hello, Gatwick Airport. This is RAF 241. How do you read me?
Gatwick Airport to RAF 241. We read you loud and clear.
Have the Chameleon aircraft in sight. Am following at ten thousand feet, heading due south.
That's him, right on the tail. So far, so good.
All set.
Something's following us.
Another airliner going the same way?
No, it's too small. It's a fighter. Give me a radar reading.
Two three decimal seven nine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade uses a targeting device then presses a button.
A beam of light hits the pilot. He screams.

Dialogue.Line: Heslington, that fighter's off course.
Gatwick to RAF 241. Do you read me?
That plane isn't just off course. Something's happened to it.
You're right. It's out of control.
Gatwick to RAF 241. Do you read me?
I don't think you'll get a reply.
It's fading, dropping out of our radar. Jean, get me RAF Manston. That plane's crashed.
Look at the Chameleon plane. There's something wrong with that too.
Hmmm?
It's standing still!
Impossible.
No, sir, the blip's stationary.
That can only mean one thing. It's crashing, too.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Actually it isn't. It is hovering, folding its wings back into the fuselage. The passenger cabin is empty. Ann picks up a small object from each seat and puts them into their own compartment in her metal container.

Dialogue.Line: Report to the flight deck immediately.
How many people require passports in order to leave the airport on the next flight.
Twenty five.
You missed this one here.
I'm sorry.
Carry on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ann returns to the main compartment, but has lost her place. Did she pick something up from Jamie's seat or not? As it is empty she assumes she must have, and moves on.
Ann comes out from the flight deck carrying the metal container. Blade is with her.

Dialogue.Line: That plane they sent to follow us, should we have destroyed it?

We could eliminate a whole squadron of their toy planes and they'd never get on to us. Their minds can't cope with an operation like this. Remember the teaching of our Director. The intelligence of Earth people is comparable only to that of animals on our planet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Blade and Ann disembark. Jamie comes out of the galley and starts to follow them, but hides again when two blank Chameleons come on board and start removing the passenger's hand luggage. Finally his chance comes, and he leaves the plane.

Ann carefully unloads the contents of the container into a cabinet drawer and leaves. Jamie watches her walk down the corridor. He intends to follow, but there are other people around so he goes into the stock room instead. The room is completely lined with tall metal cabinets full of small specimen drawers, each containing six miniaturised humans.

Dialogue.Line: I thought I'd missed one of you. I wondered what happened to you.
What have you done to them?
Close that drawer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two blank Chameleons enter and seize Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: No. No. Don't. Leave me. No, leave me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sad telephone calls are being received.

Dialogue.Line: Right, thank you. Air Sea Rescue say they're still searching but there's no trace yet.
Commandant. I see. Did the pilot managed to bail out? I'm sorry. They've found the remains of that RAF plane. The pilot had been electrocuted.
Do you still think these people are from Earth?
I don't know, Doctor. I just don't know what to think. If only there was one solid piece of evidence.
I think it's just come in. Do you mind if I question him? I think I know how to make him talk.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes over to Meadows 2, who has just come in, and shows him the white armband.

Dialogue.Line: You know what this is, don't you?
I don't know what you're talking about.
Oh I think you do. Roll up your sleeve.
Do I have to take orders from him, sir?
I think perhaps you should explain, Doctor. After all, this man is working for me.

You only think he's working for you. Commandant, your personnel are being systematically replaced, and this is how they are doing it. This is not Meadows, it only looks like Meadows. He's wearing one of these things on his arm.
Very well, do as he asks.
But sir, this is ridiculous.
We all have to help in this, Meadows. Roll up your sleeve.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meadows 2 makes a dash for the door.

Dialogue.Line: Stop him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jean pushes a chair in Meadow 2's path and he falls over it. Two other ATC restrain him.

Dialogue.Line: Now get him in this chair. Jean, send for the police. All right, Doctor, go ahead.
Roll up his left sleeve.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The black armband is revealed.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. Now then. What happens if I were to turn one of these?
Don't touch it!
Ah, I see. Right. Now then, you are going to answer all my questions, and in return, I promise no harm will come to you. Do you understand?
All right.
Where are your planes taking all their passengers?
There's a satellite about a hundred and fifty miles up.
Why are you abducting all these young people?
We had a catastrophe on our planet. A gigantic explosion. As you've seen, we have lost our identities. My people are dying out.
But what use would our people be to you?
Our scientists devised a process so that we could take on the physical characteristics of another being.
This is part of the process?
Yes, that's why you mustn't touch it.
How many of these young people do you hope to abduct?
This time, fifty thousand.
Fifty thousand!
How large is this satellite?
On the journey in our planes, the passengers are miniaturised.
I see. How many of your people are working here at Gatwick Airport?
I don't know. That's the truth, I tell you. I don't know.
Very well. What happens to the people whose identity has been taken over, the originals?
They're somewhere in the airport. I don't know exactly where.
I'll have the whole place torn to pieces to find them.
No, you mustn't find them.
Why not?
You, you mustn't, that's all.
Because if we do find them, we'll find one of these on their arms, eh? And if we remove it, something terrible will happen to you?
Yes.
What if you have to change back?
Well, that can be done, but with the machine.
The machine in the Medical Centre?
Yes. None of us know where our own originals are, except that Nurse.
Nurse? What about her?
Oh she was cunning. She's got her own original with her.
Where is it?
I don't know.
I think you do know. Now, are you going to tell me?
It's in the Medical Centre.
Right, you're going to show me where it is.
I daren't. She'll have me destroyed.
Are you going to co-operate or are you not?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two policemen enter.

Dialogue.Line: All right. It won't make any difference. You'll never see those fifty thousand young people again.
I think I'd better take him down there. The Medical Centre.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Samantha is gagged and strapped to the couch in the x-ray room. Pinto goes into the main area and opens a first aid box on the wall. She activates the monitor at the back of the box.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
This girl. What do we do with her? SPENCER [on monitor]: We need to use her as an original. That way we can get one of our people close to the man who is menacing us. He will then be killed.
But surely Captain Blade isn't bringing any more of our people to Earth?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The monitor goes blank as the Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Can I help you?
Bring him in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The policemen escort Meadows 2 into the room.

Dialogue.Line: I'm afraid I don't understand.
I think you two have something in common.
Is this man ill, officer?
Roll up your sleeves.
What are you talking about?
Officer!
Please, take your hands off me.
Certainly. (He pulls up her left sleeve.) I've seen all I want to see. I'll have that, if you don't mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He takes the pen weapon from her tunic.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, where is her original?
It's in there.
You can't go in there!
Would you rather be destroyed? Keep an eye on her, officer. Bring him along.
Sam! Sam, are you all right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor frees Samantha.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right, Sam?
Yeah. Oh, I thought I was done for there. Pins and needles.
You're lucky it was no worse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He checks her arm is sheath-free.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Just checking up. Now then, where is the Nurse's original?
It's in a panel in the wall somewhere. The control's in the couch there.
All right, Officer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The policeman releases Meadows 2 to operate the controls. The panel slides back to reveal the real Nurse, wearing the white armband.

Dialogue.Line: Flipping heck. But she's in there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the main room, Pinto 2 has been washing her hands. There is a ray gun hidden in one of the towels and she uses it on the policeman, who screams and dies. Then she goes into the x-ray room and aims it at Meadows 2.

Dialogue.Line: You traitor!
Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Before she can fire, Meadows leaps towards the real Nurse and touches her armband. Pinto 2 dissolves into a shapeless blob.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right, Sam. It's all right.
She vanished!
Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The real nurse is waking up.

Dialogue.Line: Put her on here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meadows helps her onto a couch.

Dialogue.Line: There we are.
Will there be any permanent damage?
No. You can take that off now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He takes off the nurse's armband.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right. You'll be quite all right in a few minutes. There.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sees a pile of files on a table.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, what's happened to Jamie?
What on Earth are these doing here?
Doctor, Jamie wasn't anywhere near the kiosk the last time. Look, you're not listening! I think they've got Jamie!
Jamie! Where?
Well, you should know. You got him to pinch me ticket.
Pinch your ticket?
To stop me from going to Rome.
Oh. You mean Jamie has
Has gone in my place.
First Polly and Ben, now Jamie. We've no time to lose.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tied to a chair, Jamie is struggling to get free when the door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Inspector!
Let's see if I can get you out of there. How did you get here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Crossland unties Jamie. He seems to have lost his accent somewhere.

Dialogue.Line: I came on the plane, stole someone's ticket.
You ought to have been miniaturised on the journey.
Miniaturised?
Reduced in size, like all the youngsters in these cabinets. Did you not have anything to eat or drink?
No, I felt too ill.
That explains it. The food is the first part of the process.
Inspector, what is this place?
A satellite, Jamie. A flying ship in space. These people are from another planet. It seems the Doctor was right after all. Does anyone down there believe him yet?
Oh, I'm not sure. I don't think so.
I suppose it is too much for them to believe. But surely the Doctor's convinced them that something is going on?
Aye, I think maybe the Commandant.
Yes, Jamie.
Inspector, have you escaped or something?
No-one escapes from here.
But the plane that comes here, well, it must go back to Earth. We could get on it.
The last plane to Earth is leaving now. They've just gone back to pick up their own people.
Surely the Doctor'll think of some way of rescuing us?
Not this time, Jamie. This time he's up against a mind superior even to his. The mind of the Director.
You mean someone clever than the Doctor?
The man in charge of this whole mission.
You seem to know a lot about it, Inspector.
Of course I do, Jamie. I am the Director.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The space doors open and the rocket shaped aeroplane comes out, to descend to Earth.

Dialogue.Line: And his is the bearing where the Chameleon plane vanished. I want to know if it reappears there. They've a flight due any minute.
Very good, sir.
Now then, Doctor. What's all this about personnel files?
Over here. I'll show you. I found these in the Medical Centre. Records of twenty five people who work here. Each one of these has been taken over by Chameleons.
Right. I'll have them all under arrest within fifteen minutes. Airport Police please. Now, look at this.
What is it?
Chameleon Air Schedules.
You see here? Their last flight of the season goes in an hour. Superintendent Reynolds please.
The last flight? Well that's exactly why they mustn't be arrested.
Superintendent? Commandant here.
Will you please listen to me!
Will you hold on a moment, please?
These people must not be arrested.
Why not?

Somewhere in outer space, there are fifty thousand young people, three of my friends amongst them, and somehow we've got to bring them back. I want to get on this last flight, which means the Chameleons must think that everything is going according to plan.
Commandant?
Reynolds, I'll call you back. Now what is it?
This blip. It's just appeared out of nowhere and it's coming this way.
Right, well keep tracking them. It maybe the Chameleon plane returning. Now look here, Doctor. All very well talking about getting on that plane, but how?
At the moment, you look like a man called Meadows. Could you shed that identity and become somebody else?
Yes. Yes, some of our people have been processed twice.
Good. Then in that case I shall pretend I am a Chameleon, and get on board that way.
But even if you get on that plane, what do you hope to do?
I don't know till I get to the satellite, and then I will have one card to play, and that's up to you Commandant.
What's that?
